subject: tW: What a Rubber Duck Knows
body: Hi there, Have You Spoken With the Silent Plastic Genius on Your Desk? This edition of thesify [https://app.thesify.ai/?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free14.08.25] Weekly takes a closer look at the rubber duck method, a technique mentioned in our conversation with Dr. Michael Meeuwis [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCxih0fBvsg] that deserves its own spotlight. Speaking your argument aloud to a silent plastic â€œlistenerâ€ can expose gaps in logic, tangled phrasing, and unsupported claims faster than re-reading ever could. This weekâ€™s blog post, Preserving Your Academic Voice in the AI Era [https://www.thesify.ai/blog/preserving-academic-voice-ai], goes well beyond the duck, sharing practical ways to maintain clarity, originality, and authority while ensuring AI tools support rather than replace your thinking. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This Week at thesify: Inside the Mind of a Professor The newest episode in thesifyâ€™s interview [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCxih0fBvsg] series features Dr. Michael Meeuwis, Professor of English at the University of Warwick [https://warwick.ac.uk/fac/arts/english/people/drmichaelmeeuwis/]. In this candid conversation, he explains how AI is changing academic writing and what it takes to preserve originality, clarity, and authorship. From close reading to mindful drafting, he shares strategies every student and researcher can apply. Watch the Interview on YouTube [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MCxih0fBvsg] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- This Weekâ€™s Blog: Preserving Your Academic Voice in the AI Era Your academic voice comes from the way you select evidence, build analysis, and draw conclusions. This post shares practical strategies for protecting that voice while using AI responsibly. It covers close reading, mindful drafting, targeted feedback, and aligning every source with your thesis. Drawing on insights from Dr. Michael Meeuwis, it explains how to use AI to refine and test your work while keeping authorship firmly in your hands. Read the full post [https://www.thesify.ai/blog/preserving-academic-voice-ai] -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Your Weekly Tips: Making the Rubber Duck Work for You 1. Interrogate each step of your reasoning aloud Select a short but significant section of your draft and explain it to a silent â€œlistener.â€ This could be a rubber duck, a figurine, or even a coffee mug. The value lies in hearing your own logic without external prompts or cues. As you speak, listen for points where you hesitate, reorder thoughts mid-sentence, or need to backtrack. These are likely places where your reasoning is either unclear or incomplete on the page. 2. Use stumbles as a map for revision When you lose momentum while explaining, resist the urge to dismiss it as a speaking slip. In writing, these same weak points will cause readers to slow down or misinterpret your claim. Mark these areas in your draft and work on clarifying connections, tightening evidence, or making assumptions explicit. Treat each stumble as a signal of structural work to be done, not a minor polish issue. 3. Turn thesifyâ€™s suggested topics into prompts Before you revise, run your draft through thesifyâ€™s feedback report and look at the Suggested Topics section, shown in the screenshot below. Each question is tailored to your discipline and identifies areas your draft has not yet addressed. [https://smonk.mjt.lu/img2/smonk/b38afd82-937d-473f-9ead-3b7b45c92aeb/content] Treat these as prompts for your rubber duck session, speaking through answers aloud to surface gaps in logic or evidence. This not only makes the feedback actionable but also ensures your revisions directly strengthen the conceptual backbone of your work. 4.Confirm your revisions through repetition After making targeted changes, return to the same section and speak it through again. If the flow holds steady and the logic feels complete, you have likely resolved the original problem. If not, the method will expose new points to refine. Over time, this cycle sharpens your ability to anticipate where readers will need more clarity and ensures your argument is structurally sound before you seek AI feedback. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Related Resources * thesify Weekly Newsletter Archive: [https://thesify.substack.com/] Each week, we share practical tips on writing, revision, and academic strategy. Catch up on past editions or revisit your favorites in our Substack archive * Inside Academic Ghostwriting â€“ Interview, Ethics & AI | thesify: [https://www.thesify.ai/blog/inside-academic-ghostwriting-interview?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free14.08.25] https://www.thesify.ai/blog/the-role-of-ai-in-strengthening-research-questions-tips-for-students?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free19.06.25In thesifyâ€™s first interview episode [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DvfRsX-kav8] of its new video series, we spoke with a freelance academic ghostwriter with a background in the social sciences who transitioned into the role during the early months of the pandemic. Drawing on years of experience writing for students around the world, they share firsthand insights into what the job entails, who hires them, and why. They also reflect on the growing role of generative AI tools like ChatGPT in the academic writing process. * Ethical Use Cases of AI in Academic Writing: A 2025 Guide for Students and Researchers: [https://www.thesify.ai/blog/ethical-use-cases-of-ai-in-academic-writing-a-2025-guide-for-students-and-researchers?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free14.08.25] https://www.thesify.ai/blog/from-ai-panic-to-proactive-policy-a-syllabus-roadmap-for-responsible-ai-academic-tools?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free17.07.25Understanding and adhering to AI guidelines is crucial. Ethical AI use in academic writing involves leveraging technology to enhance learning and productivity while ensuring that the work remains a product of the author's critical thinking and original insights. Learn how to avoid overreliance on AI and why using AI-generated topics without personal input or critical evaluation can lead to generic or unoriginal work. * How Professors Detect AI in Academic Writing: A Comprehensive Student Guide: [https://www.thesify.ai/blog/how-professors-detect-ai-in-academic-writing-a-comprehensive-student-guide?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free14.08.25] Professors employ AI detection tools that analyze text to identify patterns indicative of machine-generated content. Key features of these tools include writing style comparisons, which assess changes in a student's writing style across assignments to detect anomalies. Learn how to personalize your writing, maintain consistency in style, and use AI tools responsibly, ensuring your voice remains dominant and your work isnâ€™t flagged as AI-generated. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Get Feedback Anytime Without the Wait Normally, youâ€™d rely on a tutor or professor to guide you through revisions, but tutors can be costly, and professors often donâ€™t have the time to provide detailed feedback. Thatâ€™s where thesify steps in. Upgrade today! [http://app.thesify.ai?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free14.08.25] Need more insights? Visit our full blog archive [https://www.thesify.ai/blog?utm_source=thesifyai&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=free14.08.25] or newsletter archive [https://thesify.substack.com/] for expert advice on academic writing. Until next time, The thesify Team This e-mail has been sent to alexliaskosga@gmail.com, click here to unsubscribe https://smonk.mjt.lu/unsub2?hl=en&m=AVYAAHdCJeYAAc3lt4QAAgn3lDIAAYCs084AnnOGACe2dABonbl8YH2mjikXQnCpSOAbxpsgOQAk2R8&b=bba0a597&e=a29dba27&x=deIYBF-qo4sxKVsaIHorYkcPEezbcon288d-2B922ww.

subject: Alex, Veo 3 with native audio is now in the Gemini API
body: Email not displaying correctly? View it online Google AI Studio An example of a video with dialogue and audio produced using Veo 3 with a single prompt. Veo 3 is now available in the Gemini API Get started with Veo 3 Hello Alex, You can now generate high-fidelity, 720p videos with native audio using Veo 3 and Veo 3 Fast, available in paid preview in the Gemini API. Veo 3 brings your prompts to life, creating 8-second videos with native audio. It lets you generate video from a text prompt, an initial image, or a combination of both to guide the style and starting frame. It can create a wide range of visual styles and natively generate dialogue in multiple languages, as well as sound effects and ambient noise. Get started in seconds You can use our SDKs for Python, JavaScript, and Go, or make a direct REST API call with cURL. Get your API key and start generating. import time from google import genai client = genai.Client() prompt = """A close up of two people staring at a cryptic drawing on a wall, torchlight flickering. A man murmurs, 'This must be it. That's the secret code.' The woman looks at him and whispering excitedly, 'What did you find?'""" # Start the generation job operation = client.models.generate_videos( model="veo-3.0-generate-preview", prompt=prompt, ) # Poll for the result while not operation.done: print("Waiting for video generation to complete...") time.sleep(10) operation = client.operations.get(operation) # Download the final video video = operation.response.generated_videos[0] video.video.save("dialogue_example.mp4") print("Generated video saved to dialogue_example.mp4") Ready to build? Read the documentation Explore all parameters, learn advanced prompting techniques, and discover more examples. Start building Access Veo 3 Select a billing-enabled Google Cloud project for your API key and get started with Veo 3. Get API Key Happy building, The Google AI Studio team - Prompt Models - Manage API keys - Get help Â© 2025 Google Ireland Ltd, Gordon House, Barrow Street, Dublin 4, Ireland. subject: EAG Newsletter August 2025
body: August 2025 View online version https://news.eag.org/nl3/SKoRUa0SRX9ewC32YL6dZg?m=AVIAAHbomXoAAc4kdJoAAACLEGYAAAAAG4EAAA--ABo4bwBonaEASlX9RUQbRp-LEJVjtqgM0AAZTVg&b=fea3f3af&e=933191fa&x=deIYBF-qo4sxKVsaIHorYkcPEezbcon288d-2B922ww [https://www.eag.org] > [https://www.eag.org/membership/] > [https://members.eag.org/login] > [https://www.eag.org/] Goldschmidt Conferences Goldschmidt 2025 highlights Catch up on some of the highlights from Goldschmidt 2025 this summer! Explore Goldschmidt TV [https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLapLbIDXZYU3UACb3GC61MAC3blm-bPS] for meeting insights and exclusive interviews, dive into all the stories from our team of bloggers [https://www.eagblog.org/categories/goldschmidt-2025/], read the research that made international news [https://conf.goldschmidt.info/goldschmidt/2025/meetingapp.cgi/ModuleMeetingInfo/Press?clearcache=1], and watch the plenary lectures [https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLLapLbIDXZYVE7dj_68c0pdh2kH1dJid6]. > [https://conf.goldschmidt.info/goldschmidt/2025/meetingapp.cgi] Goldschmidt 2026 The 2026 Goldschmidt Conference will be held in MontrÃ©al, Canada from 12 to 17 July 2026. The call for session and workshop proposals opens on 3 September. > [https://conf.goldschmidt.info/goldschmidt/2026/meetingapp.cgi] Society News 2026 Award nominations now open [https://www.eag.org/awards/nomination/] Nominations for the 2026 Awards are open until 30 October. There have been some changes to the nomination process and guidelines, explained below. The H.C. Urey Award [https://www.eag.org/awards/urey-award/] recognizes scientists who have made outstanding contributions advancing geochemistry over a career. Significant changes were made to the nomination process; in particular, there are no more nomination letters. The Science Innovation Award [https://www.eag.org/awards/science-innovation-award/] recognizes scientists who have recently made a particularly important and innovative breakthrough in geochemistry. There are new eligibility criteria: nominees must have received a recognized doctorate within 25 years of the first day of the year in which the award is given (career breaks are taken into account). The F.G. Houtermans Award [https://www.eag.org/awards/houtermans-award/] recognizes exceptional contributions to geochemistry by an early career scientist. There are new eligibility criteria: nominees must have received a recognized doctorate within 7 years of the first day of the year in which the award is given (career breaks are taken into account). The Geochemistry Fellowship [https://www.eag.org/awards/fellows/] honors outstanding scientists who have made major contributions to the field of geochemistry. The award is based on scientific excellence as well as the broader impacts candidates have made in their careers to date. > [https://www.eag.org/awards/nomination/] EAG student sponsorship deadline: 1 September [https://www.eag.org/early-career/student-sponsorship/] The EAG Student Sponsorship Program [https://www.eag.org/early-career/student-sponsorship/] supports onsite participation at events held in Europe, or online participation at events held anywhere in the world. Successful applicants will receive sponsorship of up to 1000 euros to cover registration, abstract fees, and travel expenses where applicable. Applicants may be based in any country. Next application deadline: 1 September > [https://www.eag.org/early-career/student-sponsorship/] EAG Blogosphere EAG sponsored student Laura Piccirillo visits the French Research Institute for Ocean Science (IFREMER) [https://www.eagblog.org/news/laura-piccirillo/] [by Laura Piccirillo] I recently visited the French Institute for Ocean Science (IFREMER) in Brest, France for a 1-week short research stay, thanks to the support from the EAG Student Sponsorship Award. The main priority for this visit was to... > [https://www.eagblog.org/news/laura-piccirillo/] EAG sponsored student Kerys Meredew presents her Volcanological Research at IAVCEI2025 [https://www.eagblog.org/news/kerys-meredew/] [by Kerys Meredew] The Scientific Assembly of the International Association of Volcanology and Chemistry of the Earthâ€™s Interior (IAVCEI) was held in Geneva in July 2025 with the theme â€œThe energies of magma: From volcanic eruptions and mineral... > [https://www.eagblog.org/news/kerys-meredew/] EAG sponsored student Cathrin Wittig joins the Fjords in a Changing Climate 2025 workshop [https://www.eagblog.org/news/fjord-workshop/] [by Cathrin Wittig] I was very happy to attend the Fjord workshop 2025 in Stalheim, Norway organized by the Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research from the 2nd of June with the financial support of the EAG student sponsorship program... > [https://www.eagblog.org/news/fjord-workshop/] Important Dates and Deadlines EAG and Goldschmidt deadlines 1 September: EAG Student Sponsorship [https://www.eag.org/early-career/student-sponsorship/] application deadline 1 October: EAG Early Career Science Ambassador [https://www.eag.org/early-career/early-career-science-ambassadors/] application deadline 15 October: Goldschmidt 2026 [https://conf.goldschmidt.info/goldschmidt/2026/meetingapp.cgi]session & workshop proposals submission deadline (opens 3 Sep) 30 October: H.C. Urey, Science Innovation, and F.G. However, there is... > [https://www.geochemicalperspectivesletters.org/article2526/] [https://www.geochemicalperspectivesletters.org/article2525/] Fluid-mediated uranium isotope fractionation in magmatic systems Uranium isotopes fractionation behaviour during magmatic differentiation and magmatic-hydrothermal processes remains unclear. Student travel request (extended): 15 August Abstract submission: 31 August > [https://www.iseb-2025.org/] EAGE GET 2025, 27-31 October, Rotterdam: early registration 1 September [https://eageget.org/] The EAGE Global Energy Transition Conference & Exhibition (GET 2025 [https://eageget.org/]) is the premier event highlighting the application of geoscience and engineering skills towards the energy transition. The conference will feature four specialized technical tracks: Offshore Wind Energy, Carbon Capture & Storage, Geothermal Energy, and Hydrogen & Energy Storage. Showcase the latest innovations and discussions on Geochemistry applied to reactive transport modelling for CCS; reservoir and seal challenges for energy storage, and more. Early/regular registration: 1 September / 1 October > [https://eageget.org/] SIMP-SGI Joint Congress, Padua, 16-18 September: registration 5 September [https://en.geoscienze.org/padua2025/] This congress with the theme "The Geosciences and the Challenges of the 21st Century" aims to be a space for meeting, dialogue, and discussion, highlighting the crucial role of Geosciences in building our future, on Earth and beyond. Discover the scientific sessions here [https://en.geoscienze.org/893/list-of-topics-and-sessions.html]. Registration closes: 5 September EAG members can register at member rate > [https://en.geoscienze.org/padua2025/] AFEQ-CNF INQUA symposium, Paris 6 November - registration 30 September [https://variabilite.sciencesconf.org/?lang=fr] We are pleased to announce the next specialized session of the SGF [https://www.geosoc.fr/] organized by the AFEQ [https://afeq.hypotheses.org/]-CNF INQUA. The conference will be held in French and will focus on changes in past climates, with particular attention to their variability, seasonality and extreme events. The aim is to bring the â€œpalaeoâ€ community together around scientific presentations, with an emphasis on projects currently being carried out in France. subject: INVITATION Science for Breakfast with Medicon Village Innovation
body: Invitation View in browser Link: https://tr.apsis.one/web/kVfzvsJNRZ-XfwlKEd2qKQ/ln_k7S5sVSXV6YTRYY4ANzgJ TUESDAY 19 AUG @ 08:30 - 09:30 Science for Breakfast with Medicon Village Networking, knowledge sharing and energy build-up! Science for Breakfast is an initiative by Medicon Village to facilitate networking and knowledge sharing among scientists and entrepreneurs in the village and others. Welcome back from the holidays! Join us for Science for Breakfast, as we welcome everyone back from the holidays! We're kicking off the season with a great opportunity to connect with others and discover more about the vibrant community at Medicon Village â€“ over a tasty breakfast. A perfect start to your autumn Tuesday mornings at Medicon Village!Speakers: Petter Hartman, CEO, and Sarah LidÃ©, Deputy CEO, at Medicon Village Innovation.Healthy breakfast buffet is provided on behalf of Medicon Village. Bring your colleaguesâ€“ everyone is welcome, just remember to sign up! Tuesday, 19 August08:30 - 09:30 The SparkÂ´s Lounge (1st floor), Medicon Village, Scheeletorget 1, Lund.
